Great for $100
I got this phone to replace a ZTE Blade I got for a friend who is pushing 70
She has TMobile service, and was using the MetroPCS 1st or 2nd gen Blade with a 6 display, USB-C connector, fingerprint reader, and 4000mah battery
The subsidized cost of that phone was also about $100, four years ago
Recently my girlfriend switched to Visible (Verizon CDMA), and got a Blade A7
This is a fantastic phone, but at $79 the cost was only about half its actual market value
Full disclosure, I like ZTE, andhave owned both their cheap and flagship phones
I tested this phone using an AT&T SIM with no data, depending on WiFi, so please take that into account
First let's take a look at what's good on this phone
Better than MediTek, and competive with Qualcomm 500 series
The lack of RAM was almost always the bottleneck
Washed out for everyday apps
-Good stock software, the applications, and widget options etc, were well thought out, and designed to appeal to an entry level user
The Bad- and the first two are really bad
The charging, as a consequence, could not have been any slower, and harkens me back to the day when a frantic friend with a walwart was always looking for an outlet
-Battery life- with the 8 core chipset, the 3250mah battery can last a full day on a full charge with moderate use, but the Micro USB charging aims to keep it from ever reaching full charge
-No 5ghz WiFi, again, how is this even possible in something calling itself 2020?While the 2
I was only able to get about 15mbps download speed with a 1000mbps wifi connection
That is why this has Android 9, because it needs the pattern unlock
Now to its credit, the face unlock feature woked very well
The 32GB of storage is great at this pricepoint, and phones costing 50% more come with2 or 3GB,I would've liked to have seen more
Verdict- This is the iPhone 10R for the Android crowd
It really has eveything a person over 60 could want
That crowd cannot figure out fingerprint readers anyway
The over 60 crowd cares about the camera, the software, and watching Netflix on their phone
That is who this phone is aimed at, and for that consumer, it is an excellent choice
For the rest of us, we just need to belly up to the bar and pay $200 for something like a OnePlus Nord N100, or something like that
Other phones near this price point from Motorola try to do too much, and are a poor choice for an older consumer
Nokia has entered the market at the low end too, but both of those options start at $150
The Blackview A60, which is one of the few phones on Amazon that can compete at this pricepoint, does not even run full Android
If you only have $100, this is a really great option
NOT 4G as advertised
Since AT&T shut down their 3G network in our area this phone stopped working, despite the claimed 4G capability
The phone itself is a little slow to open apps, battery life is pretty impressive, but I feel the seller MOBILES INTERNATIONAL should be called out for a dishonest listing description
Oh well, back to phone shopping

Great for $100
I got this phone to replace a ZTE Blade I got for a friend who is pushing 70
She has TMobile service, and was using the MetroPCS 1st or 2nd gen Blade with a 6 display, USB-C connector, fingerprint reader, and 4000mah battery
The subsidized cost of that phone was also about $100, four years ago
Recently my girlfriend switched to Visible (Verizon CDMA), and got a Blade A7
This is a fantastic phone, but at $79 the cost was only about half its actual market value
Full disclosure, I like ZTE, andhave owned both their cheap and flagship phones
I tested this phone using an AT&T SIM with no data, depending on WiFi, so please take that into account
First let's take a look at what's good on this phone
Better than MediTek, and competive with Qualcomm 500 series
The lack of RAM was almost always the bottleneck
Washed out for everyday apps
-Good stock software, the applications, and widget options etc, were well thought out, and designed to appeal to an entry level user
The Bad- and the first two are really bad
The charging, as a consequence, could not have been any slower, and harkens me back to the day when a frantic friend with a walwart was always looking for an outlet
-Battery life- with the 8 core chipset, the 3250mah battery can last a full day on a full charge with moderate use, but the Micro USB charging aims to keep it from ever reaching full charge
-No 5ghz WiFi, again, how is this even possible in something calling itself 2020?While the 2
I was only able to get about 15mbps download speed with a 1000mbps wifi connection
That is why this has Android 9, because it needs the pattern unlock
Now to its credit, the face unlock feature woked very well
The 32GB of storage is great at this pricepoint, and phones costing 50% more come with2 or 3GB,I would've liked to have seen more
Verdict- This is the iPhone 10R for the Android crowd
It really has eveything a person over 60 could want
That crowd cannot figure out fingerprint readers anyway
The over 60 crowd cares about the camera, the software, and watching Netflix on their phone
That is who this phone is aimed at, and for that consumer, it is an excellent choice
For the rest of us, we just need to belly up to the bar and pay $200 for something like a OnePlus Nord N100, or something like that
Other phones near this price point from Motorola try to do too much, and are a poor choice for an older consumer
Nokia has entered the market at the low end too, but both of those options start at $150
The Blackview A60, which is one of the few phones on Amazon that can compete at this pricepoint, does not even run full Android
If you only have $100, this is a really great option
NOT 4G as advertised

I've been using an iPhone since smartphone was a word
Enter the Essential Phone
I needed a phone that was fast, and could do basic things, like phone calls, Dropbox, Trello, Slack, email, and web-browsing
The KeyOne would have been too slow (I need a responsive device that doesn't break the user experience by freezing up)
The Essential Phone has a large, beautiful screen in a diminutive chassis that is smaller and slightly heavier than my 6S Plus
The rest of the Essential Phone is just as gorgeous as the screen
The phone does everything that I want it to, and it is extremely fast
Switching from an iPhone to this was a phenomenal decision
Side note about the camera: The photos do look a little lifeless, but they are extremely sharp
Superb Phone
I received my Essential PH-1 the beginning of August, 2018
I have now used it for a full three weeks
This is the first pure android phone I have owned
The design of this phone is great too
Updates were immediate
I am not really experiencing the focus delay, or any other issues
This phone has fast charging, but is crazy picky about the cord you use
Reception on this phone is terrific
To sum up this phone, it is a high end phone
If you are thinking of getting the Essential PH-1, you really need to
The highest performing Phone I've used to date
I've been using this phone for ~2 months with daily use ranging from extensive to moderate
The decision to purchase this phone came with much trepidation - reviews in 20017 were sour on the phones camera, lag, screen jitters, and cost
The price drop was the final motivation to purchase this phone as a replacement for my Nexus 6
After 2 months of solid use, I have absolutely no complaints - in fact, I love this phone
I'm a big fan of an unmolested Android UI and this has exactly what I'm looking for
As a former owner of all of the larger device manufacturers (Motorola, LG, HTC, Apple, etc
Essential staying with a stock Android UI allows the PH-1 to operate very fast, hold a charge for almost 2 days with moderate use, and supports honest multi-tasking
Like you, the camera feedback was a big concern for me
The camera reviews received little love, and from what I read, this was deserved
In fact, last night I received another camera update
The new portrait feature has been put through the paces on the phone and is a great feature with solid results
At this point, I'd stack the camera on this phone up to almost any phone with the possible exception of Samsung and Pixel
So think about it, there are dozens of other phone manufactures that produce similar if not inferior photo quality to the Essential PH-1

Using the last 6 months as a barometer, the velocity of updates for the camera that we have seen will certain further enhancement photo quality and eliminate all of the concerns for the point and shoot recreational photographer
The bezel-less screen, color contrast, and sharpness are on par with my Apple iPhone
When comparing the screen size to the Apple 8 Plus, the Essential PH-1 has a larger overall useful screen size (eliminating the dead black space around the iPhones's screen)
The benefit is a mini-phablet display without the bulk and size of a large phone that I would struggle to put in my pant pocket or mount to a dashboard phone holder
I haven't bench marked the performance of this phone against others as others have done this and you can find the objective data on various Android sites
The objective data speaks very positively for this phone
Did it perform to my expectations, are there shortfalls that amplified themselves, would I buy this phone again, etc
The areas where I had low expectations, the phone has proven to shine and the concerns weren't manifested
The only features/attributes I wish this phone had were waterproofing and wireless charging
I've grown accustomed to the missing headphone jack but would really like to see the other items addressed in the next iteration of this phone
Based on my demand for a phone and daily usage demand, I would highly recommend this phone
To date, it is the best phone I've owned
I am happy with returning my Pixel 2 in a few days
I've been using the Essential Phone for close to a month now, and am currently reviewing it after receiving my Pixel 2 phone a few days ago to test both
After playing around with the controversial camera on both devices, I am happy with returning my Pixel 2 in a few days
This leaves the physical build, price, screen and battery life as the determining factors
The build quality and aesthetics of the Essential wins hands-down for me
So is the price
Which brings me to the battery
In the end, I feel like the Essential is a better match for me
If you're not picky but want a solid smart phone, essential ph1 is for you

-Lack of Waterproofing - While many newer phones are water resistant, the Essential phone forgoes this feature
-No Expandable Storage - This also doesn't bother me because I will never even fill up the 128gb of internal storage, but for those that would like this option, you're out of luck with this phone

-No Wireless Charging - While Essential is supposedly working on a charging dock that connects via the magnetic pins, it doesn't support wireless charging on the Qi standard, which is an inconvenience for those who are used to this feature

-Smooth Design - While it feels great to hold in your hand, the smooth design of this phone means that it will easily slide off smooth surfaces (like pants), so putting this phone on your lap without a case could lead to an unfortunate fall
-Limited Selection of Device Protection - While there are more cases and screen protectors out now than a month ago, there aren't as many options as there are for other devices

While there are some downsides to this phone that may deter some people from purchasing it, the Essential Ph-1 is a truly great device, especially when you consider that this is the company's first phone

My new favorite phone of all time

I do a LOT of research on phones, so I read all the horror stories about Essential's PH1 before I bought in: stories of terrible connectivity, earpiece fabric falling out, glitching phones, and all the bad reports
Despite that, I read that Essential was working hard and updating the phone almost continuously, trying to fix issues
When I broke my last phone, and Amazon starting having sales on the PH-1, I jumped onboard
The constant updates (and Android version upgrades) show that they're really putting their all into making this phone into what the original vision of it was
Be careful laying it down if you don't use cases
First off, the interface is blazing fast
This is my first phone to have stock Android, and the difference to me is night and day
It opens apps, loads, and just navigates so fluidly, it's put me off Android skins for the foreseeable future
Essential has been publishing updates almost constantly, and for the Android P release, I got it the SAME DAY as Google's phone
That is unheard of in Android Land, and really speaks to the commitment the software team has for this phone
Battery life is great too
I charge it every 1
5-2 days, and that's with the occasional Pokemon Go or YouTube marathon
The phone is built very well, and the ceramic and titanium give it a very distinct appearance
I've had several people ask me what phone I had, so it does get noticed
The only downside is that beautiful ceramic back is a lot slicker than a glass back, and it will take headfirst dives off of surfaces you THOUGHT were completely flat
I've had my phone take two jumps, and both times, both it and I were completely motionless before it tried to commit suicide
I have noticed, like some people have said, a little weaker signal quality than my last phone
This has only been a problem in a couple places, like in my gym where I have NO signal, but overall it hasn't bothered me
As long as there is a signal, I get great call quality consistently
The camera is still not the greatest, but it is definitely better with Essential's many updates to it
The major deficit is low-light, where it really struggles
I compare my photos to my wife's on her iPhone 8 Plus, and the iPhone in low light is the clear winner
Some people have side-loaded Google's camera app and had better results, but I haven't tried this
In conclusion, despite the few shortcomings, I LOVE this phone
I haven't had any of the maddening issues that some have had, and my phone has performed exceedingly well

I would be willing to say the this has taken the place of my favorite smartphone that I've ever owned, and even if Essential doesn't do a PH-2, I feel confident they will continue to support this phone for a long time
I'll be running this one until it gives out on me
great phone camera ok
This phone is truly great

No problems otherwise
Would be a Decent Phone--if it Wasn't for Manufacturer Defects

A sleek, fast smartphone that competes with Apple and Samsung for half the price? Sign me up!That's what hooked me on this phone, but after a rocky 45 days with the phone--leading to it essentially destroying itself--I remember thinking that this phone was too good to be true
For the past three years, I've been buying budget smartphones from Samsung
About the company: this phone didn't sell as well as Essential hoped
Let me tell you, the Essential Phone was not the way to go
After receiving the phone, I immediately noticed how sleek and beautiful it was--the fingerprint sensor on the back of the phone was honestly one of my favorite qualities due to its location
A week later, the phone updated the Android Operating System and became the fastest phone I have ever used in my entire life, even faster than my friend's brand-new Samsung S9+
Two weeks after this, the screen started glitching
While laying in bed one night, about to go to sleep--two weeks later--the phone wouldn't connect to my WiFi network, so I restarted it
I took it in to my carrier who worked on it for about 30 minutes but agreed that it was a problem with the phone itself, not the SIM Card
Bottom Line: if you're willing to risk a manufacturing problem with a company that is unstable, go for it

One year in and it's working like new, no lag, tons of storage and good camera

1 Year Updated Review
-The plastic layer between the titanium and screen is clearly visible on the white model, but the 2 layers are perfectly flush to the micrometer level

-The weight (in combination with the ceramic) definitely gives the phone a premium feeling--Hardware:-Yes the camera is sub-par, Essential has been pushing software updates for the camera, but the lack of OIS and the relatively bad low-light performance are hardware issues and cannot be fixed with software
-Monochrome camera, just
-I've found that the speakers are decently loud (definitely louder than my Note Edge)
-Fingerprint scanner is fast and responsive, but the screen takes half a second to turn on

-The Snapdragon 835 is nice and snappy and can handle split screening without a hiccup (no pun intended)-Battery life for me has been in the 8+ hour screen on time (SOT) range, despite being a below average 3,000 mAh cell

-Something that's amusing, useful, and annoying all at the same time is that the Essential phone will act as a battery bank if connected to another phone via USB-C, as in, it'll charge the other phone
-The screen is good, viewing angles are good, and colors are decent, its not AMOLED, but it's not that noticeable-The bezels are slim, not the slimiest, but definitely enough to stand out
-The notch, hate it or love it, but it normally sits in the notification bar, and is only 1 item wide
--Software-Stock Android is great, no annoying UI overlays or custom launchers
-Essential has been fast to post updates, and the unlocked bootloader is appreciated

1 Year update:Phones still going strong, software updates from Essential are still comingSomething to note is that the battery life has been reduced to about 5-7 hours screen on time with Android 9Original review still stands, except that I would not advise buying one for anything more than $250 due to the age

I'm coming off of two Sony units which unfortunately I shattered
I'll give this one a full 4
5 in durability and that puts it ahead of the otherwise very good Sony Xperia's I've had
The ample internal storage is a 5
0 rated bonus too
So what's the hold up and why do I rate this a 4?It's because of the camera
Now that is when the cameras began to get fairly good with some definite room for improvement in ultimate clarity and varied light resolution
That seems to be the hold-up here
The clarity at times is very good and others not so good
Is this operator error?After almost two and a half-yeas I don't think so
I think the camera is a bit spotty to use a term our Brit brothers love
Low light is always a gamble and average photo scenarios are, well, average more often than not
Software updates only helped marginally and I've learned to live with the limits
Calls are mostly good but this isn't a super star robust receiver, again pretty average
Sound clarity on call is average
The actual phone's speaker (one I think) is decidedly not up to the best of the mid-range current crop
These things noted the screen is excellent
The screen works pretty well in bright environments and indoors it's a treat
Videos look almost as good as my wife's iPhone X with the OLED screen
The screen is impressive as it is one of those high 90% ones without hardly a bezel
The size is perfect and it can work one-handed when you've become acclimated to using it this way
Overall it is good enough at a low price which is what most of us users bought it at instead of the initial higher price when it was first introduced
The audio quality over BT is fine with the varied BT headphones and earphones I own
It will mate easily in my experience
The updates to Android are only second to Google's Pixel models as this phone has been continuously updated to the latest Android OS systems often only weeks after Google rolls out a new OS
The wired headphone adapter works as expected and probably raises the audio quality bar importantly for some
It will decode HD music too without problems
I'm not quite ready to buy a new phone as a result of the many pluses I've mentioned in spite of the camera being pedestrian by the latest standards I have to say
The fact that I've not broken it is huge as I've had issue with many previous phones

It's sad there won't apparently be a new Essential phone, but if you can get this one at a low price there's only the camera issue which when considering pluses versus the just OK camera still makes this a compelling choice

Great phone, and don't get all worked up over the camera
The Essential Phone has a lot to offer: stock Android, great screen, decent battery life, and expansive storage
Some people complain about the camera, but I find it to be quite good
The camera software could use some improvement--more manual controls, for example--but portrait mode works well, and I find the color reproduction to be quite good
Some people complain about the camera, but I think it's a tempest in a teapot
If you *really* care about photography, you can't beat a DSLR or good mirrorless camera
Essential has made several camera improvements, and they say there are more to come
To me, the biggest drawback to the Essential Phone is memory management

After keeping the phone on for a while (days rather than hours), performance degrades noticeably, and it also degrades when I have several memory-hog apps open simultaneously--although that problem is typically solved by simply closing the offending apps
Not a huge problem, but a little surprising considering the specs

After having a U11 break (both sides after sliding out of my cup holder in my car and into the seat rail) within 6 months of purchase, I wanted something other than a glass backed phone--really, why would essentially (no pun intended) every phone company start putting glass on the back of a phone so that it can break on both sides?The Essential PH-1 uses a ceramic back that is more durable than glass
It is also some amazingly new material that is even more slippery than Teflon
The phone slips off of everything
I having lunch with a friend and the table wasn't perfectly level and it was literally sliding toward the edge
We could both see it moving!I waited about 20-30 seconds and stopped it from falling off of the table but had to block it with my wallet

Fast forward to nearly two whole months of ownership and the thing fell out of my pocket while I was sitting at my desk and shattered the screen when it hit the floor--from a whole 17 off the ceramic tiles
I do like the finger reader on the back and the size
I do like the stripped down 7
1 interface but c'mon, you have exactly ONE LEGACY PHONE to support and 8
0 has been out for months—I’m not interested in the beta version that has been on their website for a dozen weeks
I will say that the guys gave me a replacement for a couple of hundred dollars and that was really cool of them
That’s 5 star service right there!The hardware could stand to be better though
I think the biggest issue with the screen is that it sticks about 0
It has a nice radius that makes the glass look really nice as it blends into the titanium but if it hits on the corner or on the screen--it shatters
it’s also infinitely thin on the edge as it meets the titanium frame and I'm sure that doesn't help maintain an intact screen
Hopefully we’ll see an improvement from these guys with the PH-2
I suppose most folks use a case but I refuse to do that
Let’s just go back to ugly plastic phones if we’re going to need a case huh?I REALLY wanted to love this phone and I do really appreciate the customer support
The U11 guys never responded when I tried to get it fixed
Essential was super helpful right away!That alone is reason to try them again and if they get the hardware right I certainly will
I'm between 2 and 3 stars on this guy: minus 1 for software and minus 2 for hardware but the support was outstanding and I'm going to give this a solid 3

I wanted to wait until I've used this phone for awhile before rating it
I've had it for about 6 weeks now
Like any new phone, it took a little while to learn how to use it
The feature that I like the most about the phone is being able to instantly open it with a fingerprint on the back
I also like that I can program more than one fingerprint to unlock my phone
I previously had a very popular, and much more expensive, brand and was never able to get the fingerprint feature to work on that phone
The battery life is better than any phone I've every owned before
Many times, at the end of the day, I still have 75% to 80% left on the battery life, after 14 to 15 hours since the last charge
I usually charge it for about 30 minutes in the morning, and it's back up to 100%
The only down side that I had with the phone was that it doesn't use the same type of charger that most Android phones use
None of the chargers, or the car charger that I already owned, will work with the Essential Phone
The cost of the phone is so much less than what I've purchased in the past that it's worth an inconvenience, or two
After getting used to the phone, I have been very happy with many of the features and the ease of use
I would definitely recommend this phone to anyone that likes Androids

It's very nice that I didn't have to start off with unlocking the bootloader and installing custom ROMS like I would with Xiaomi, Huawei, or the other phones that can compete on price
The camera is very good not spectacular, performance is stellar, storage is spectacular
The size of the phone is what really sets it apart, good luck finding another with such a great foot print
I want to be able to use my phone with one hand, and have it fit in my pocket all day
My only wish is that the sides were rounded instead of flat, as that makes it easier to grip
I also like the fingerprint scanner on the front, but it appears everything is trending away from that anyway
All in all, no regrets
Would I spend $800 for this phone (or any phone), no
Would I spend 499, yes
Would I spend 399, all day

Verizon Server Error fix
If your on Verizon and cannot make calls or receive calls (SERVER ERROR) after you activate the phone here is what to do

Network & Internet-Mobile Network- Advanced- Turn OFF Enhanced 4G LTE Mode-Preferred network type: switch to GLOBAL- Wait 30 seconds-Attempt a phone call(If this doesn't work cycle the phone, should reset)Good luck! I've owned two of these after I had a bad streak breaking my phones or dropping them into The Drink
Right off the bat the most important thing you need to know is that they stopped offering Security Updates in February of 2020, so keep that in mind when you consider buying a new phone
The battery started strong for me, but after several hundred cycles, it dies pretty quickly, and doesn't hold up to the cold of ski mountain (shuts down)
I plan on replacing the battery at this point
The fingerpring reader is nice, but if you have a case with a credit card holder sticky on it, like me, you have to be careful not to block it
The cameras have worked really nicely, better than any previous phone I had
Charging is fast
Screen is bright and responsive
I plan on trying to get at least another year out of this phone, but will be replacing the battery and perhaps getting the 360 camera
You might also consider the OnePlus 6T, which I believe continues to have security updates

This phone has a ton of love/hate and divided opinions
Knowing this, and doing a lot of research before buying it - while fully intending to return it if I ran into the myriad issues reported- here is my experience so far
I have the newer revision white model and it came with stock 7
Right out of the box I updated it to the last OTA offered, I think I took two total OTA updates with reboots
Being an experienced Nexus phone-haver and rooting/romming/tinkering with 6 different nexus phones and tablets, I also was excited to sideload the 8
0 Oreo beta 2
I unlocked the bootloader and reboot/auto wiped
Then I sideloaded the Oreo beta 2 factory image with no issue
I fully expected to be risking a beta experience with this phone due to its reputation, but after all updates and Oreo upgrade, I have not seen any of the issues people slam this phone for
The OS is very smooth, scrolling lag isn't a thing for me, the touch response is slightly less sensitive than my Nexus 6p which I just moved from but isn't a problem
Now the camera app
Coming into this phone after the devs have been updating the phone and app it isn't as bad as reviews from even a month ago, but compared to the nexus/pixel camera app it still isn't even close
But it does work now
Please note you have to update the camera app from the Play Store after upgrading the OS as well, make sure it is always updated as the devs work on it quite a bit
Battery life is great, I had about 3 hours of SOT with heavy use yesterday and after 14 hours still had 45% left
Way better than my N6p
Only weird things I've noticed are that the Amazon Shopping app and Prime Video apps will not work, they come up with the splash screen and then go black or never log in
I have to swipe them away from the recent screen
Not sure who's to blame there, app devs or Essential
Overall this phone is fast, I love having 128GB of storage, and all the apps I use except Amazon apps work as expected
I would recommend this phone without any problem
Feels great, looks amazing, and is performing well
Great phone. Don't believe the negativity

Most other devices, even those that connect through USB type C use some type of Qualcomm fast charge
The Nintendo Switch is another device that uses USB Power Delivery and therefore chargers are interchangeable with it

The other day I got an update for my headphone dongle
The bugs have been all but entirely eradicated and the camera has improved drastically, I have no problem with the camera app right now, it is not perfect, but it takes good pictures reliably

My choice for a new phone was between the Pixel 2, the Essential, and the OP5T
Thus I imported the Essential PH-1 to Germany, and I so far I've been very happy with it
I flashed the Oreo beta onto it, and the performance is generally pretty good, I couldn't reproduce most of the common issues with this phone
I had a lot of random reboots on beta 1 (and also some on beta 2), but those were caused by me rooting the device
I hope my rather lengthy review could help you in your decision

Another PSA on replacement parts availability:Currently, Essential doesn't sell any replacement parts for it's phone, so GET A CASE! The phone is rather slippery on the back, and tends to slide off flat, slightly angled surfaces (like a tiling ledge in the bath room
I heard though that Essential is pretty nice on replacing the whole phone if you pay a small sum
For a preview, it has been pretty stable for me (apart from a few sudden reboots), and I'm extremely happy with the update support Essential is giving

It seems that the battery life actually increased in this preview as well, it seems that Android's new Adaptive battery works wonders (I got over 8 hours of SOT a few days ago, with only 20 percent recharging in between, playing Ingress afterwards, which is a heavy battery drainer normally)

I really wanted to like this phone
The screen is nice and bright
I liked how there is very little bezel around it, and the screen is all you really see
The phone is fast at processing and transitioning from one thing to the next
The battery life on the phone is incredible and I would get about a day and a half of use from it before needing to be charged
So the major construction of the phone is titanium and ceramic
I cannot figure out why that little piece broke either
I did not drop the phone and it's only been in and out of my pocket or sitting on my desk at work
When making a phone call the earpiece is built into the very top of the phone, and if you didn't get it just right to your ear, you could barely hear the conversation
Plus the top of the phone is a little sharp, and trying to find the right spot on your ear can be ever so slightly painful as it scrapes your ear
While using the speaker phone, the speaker had a slight vibration to it that you could hear at certain times
I heard it often enough that it bothered me

The screen is marketed as a full screen which it is when you are just looking at the home screen, but as soon as you go into any app or webpage, the only visible part ofscreen is below the front facing camera, so your actual usable screen is smaller and not full screen
The reception also seems to be really bad
I would drop calls, or have to walk outside my office to get any kind of reception
I have returned this phone, and I hope that in the future it gets better, I may try it again
But for now, I picked up a Huawei Mate 9, and for the short time I have had it, I like that much more
But I will do a separate review for that later

High performer

I'll start off with this, if you want a phone with DSLR quality photos and Bose quality dual driver sound you need to accept that you have to spend some coin and look to Google's pixel 2 or Samsung's note8

But sparing that I can say that this phones camera is not the terrible plague the internet seems so fond to describe it as, and the phone may have only one bottom facing speaker but it is f***ing loud and sounds very clear, I like to listen to NPR as I walk my dog and with this phone I turn the volume to about 3/4 and put it in my waist band and I can hear every detail perfectly, I love it

The battery is very average, that said average is lasting like 9-10 hours with regular use so if you're so self entitled that youspit at any phone whose battery doesn't last more than 24 hours straight with constant use, go bother some other company with your litany of bothersome complaints, this battery is fine and serves me Way better than my old Nexus 6p
Now let's talk screen, love it
7 inches, almost no bezel, really crisp clean image with sharp edges

One gripe, and it's one I hope to solve soon, it's very difficult to find a decent screen protector, that said, I'm actually hesitant to cover it anyway because this thing is a real pleasure to look at anyway
Apps load quickly, photo editing is easy enough and multitasking is without any performance lag
I have found that none of my apps crash in background on this phone
That blows my mind since my 6p and my moto-x before it had this problem frequently and it was disruptive

My 2 cents, if you're considering a new phone that is bloat free and has good solid performance but don't have the paper to buy an $800 trophy, grab this one up, even if in two years essential is liquidated I still love this phone and it will be my little collectors item when time comes to replace it

Don't hesitate, it's a good choice that is still getting better with each update, that's not common in the mobile phone market so dont miss this chance because you're nervous, just pull the trigger and enjoy it!

My first impression of this phone was great
It was beautiful
I loved the size, the screen, and the performance

Very soon after receiving it, however, I noticed that when answering incoming call, (I was using it on Verizon Wireless), 90% of the time, I could not hear the caller, and the caller could not hear me
After 10-12 seconds, there was a slight but audible 'pop' from the phone, and then both sides could hear the call fine
The problem is, most of the time the person calling would have already hung up the phone after this long of a delay
I thought this problem might be related to my Martian mvoice watch, so I completely disabled it, but the problem persisted
The replacement arrived on a Friday and worked properly for the entire weekend, making me think that my first phone had just been defective
Monday morning, the exact same issue started happening again with the replacement phone
I reached out to Essential and received absolutely no help
No amount of factory resetting or installing all available updates would get the phone to work properly
I finally had to return the second phone to Amazon as well, and even though this phone COULD have been really nice, I would not recommend it
Remember it's not an iPhone or samsung, so no need to compare them

As a tech enthusiast, and someone who is very much invested in the Google/Android ecosystem, when I first came across info regarding the Essential Ph-1, I was immediately interested
As hardware and design goes, the device is an love letter to the industry that Andy Rubin and his peers ( obviously the late Steve Jobs is another crucial figure ) founded

But for a smartphone that was sold at a premium when it first launched, the software was underbaked, making for an less than desirable day to day use, as per highly acclaimed tech reviewers on YouTube, and rightly so
Fast forward to January 2018, and several discounts, quality of life software updates, and continued support from the Essential team, have made this phone a steal for around $400 on Amazon

So yeah, all in all, for some $400-500 (depending on the retailer), I feel this was an amazing purchase, and I certainly hope Essential as a company last long enough to prove they can be the next Samsung or Apple, or even surpass these two dinosaurs
The smartphone gets 5* from me, in its current state, but mostly because I appreciate the attention to detail in the hardware design
1 rolls out, I'm confident many of the small issues still present will be ironed out
My advice is, once you decide to purchase this phone, and insert the SIM card of your carrier of choice, do a quick search on how to further optimize the phone on your on
Hope this helps! Take care!
